question: What was Ming Tjong's initial experience with housing costs in San Francisco?
answer: When Ming Tjong moved from Nashville to San Francisco in 1995, he was shocked by the high cost of living. In Nashville, he paid $400 for a two-bedroom apartment, but in San Francisco, the prices were much higher.
source_text: so the housing story housing story is um first when I moved from Nashville to San Francisco I was shocked the price everything was so expensive compared to Nashville back in 1995 so I used to live in two bedrooms apartment in Nashville and I paid maybe four hundred dollars for that

question: Why did Ming Tjong decide to buy a house in 2005?
answer: Ming Tjong and his family were living in a 900 square feet, two-bedroom apartment with five people, which was too small. They were forced to buy a house in 2005 because of the lack of space.
source_text: but right after my before my son was born actually my brother-in-law came and and they lived with us so and when my son was born it was five of us with the 900 square feet it was definitely too small so even though we were not ready in 19 2000 2004 2005. even though I was we were not ready to buy any house but we have to we were forced to buy a house in 2005 because uh five of us living in 900 square feet with two bedroom is almost like there is no space for everyone thats the reason why we have to buy the house in 2005.

question: How did Ming Tjong manage to buy a house in San Francisco?
answer: Ming Tjong bought a house in 2005 by taking advantage of a good credit score, which allowed him to pay a five percent down payment. He was eligible for a zero down payment program but chose to pay five percent.
source_text: we still remember I still remember in 2005. we paid only five percent on payment for the house even that time because of our credit score was good I would I would say excellent we were uh actually we were eligible to pay seared on payment that time so if I didnt take the zero down payment we paid five percent

question: What impact did the 2008 housing collapse have on Ming Tjong's property?
answer: During the 2008 housing collapse, the price of Ming Tjong's house in San Francisco dropped by 15-20% for a few months but then quickly recovered.
source_text: and it turns out in 2008 there was a housing collapse because I think the bank was a little bit too aggressive so yeah so a long story short we owned the house in 43rd Avenue right now for the last 17 years and we are really grateful for that

question: What challenges does Ming Tjong see in owning both a house and a business in San Francisco?
answer: Ming Tjong sees owning both a house and a business in San Francisco as almost impossible for middle-class families due to high costs. It's a dream that requires significant financial resources.
source_text: I think thats a very very difficult you know I would say its almost impossible because owning a business in San Francisco is one thing but only your house nearby your business I think thats a thats everyones dream yeah so I think theres two different things because uh owning your house thats one thing thats very difficult its like lets just put it this way its an American Dream to have your own house in big city like San Francisco so odinga house thats very hard and its even harder owning a business and also on your uh uh house and business nearby thats almost impossible

question: What is the issue with building new housing in dense communities in San Francisco?
answer: If you build new housing in a very dense community and don't provide parking space, it will frustrate people.
source_text: if you built a new housing in like a very dense community and you dont provide parking space you will make everyone get so angry I mean they they will be frustrated 100 so parking space please do plant parking space

question: What challenges do young graduates face in buying a house in San Francisco?
answer: Young graduates face challenges in buying a house in San Francisco because they are often unaware of how expensive housing is until they realize they need to work many years to afford it.
source_text: I think that a young person who just graduated from college I think thats they they have no clue or maybe they they have a lot of problems to generate money to buy a house in San Francisco so yeah after they graduate from college they dont know how much how expensive is the housing in San Francisco so when the reality kicks in they know wow I need to work another 35 years straight and then we and yeah and all my income has to be putting in the safe in order for me to afford the house in San Francisco
